docs.lead_paragraph: Jack Collins doesn't claim to be much of a farmer anymore. He no longer has time to milk his cows. The livestock on his small farm here in southern New Jersey share a ramshackle old barn, and sometimes they have to wait until 8:30 at night to get fed. But when his brood of chicks began to disappear mysteriously last fall, it didn't take long for Mr. Collins to get rid of the culprit, a marauding barn cat.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Beth Lee came home from the hospital, just 30 hours after the birth of her first child, she was tired and overwhelmed. A photographer's agent, she had no experience with newborns and couldn't remember when she had last changed a diaper. Yet there in her arms was Sophie Renee, a tiny alien presence with enormous needs. In an age of short maternity stays, women are being nudged out of the hospital in one or two days, often before they can attend child care classes and generally before breast milk starts flowing. What's more, professional women like Ms. Lee have often spent decades at work and have acquired few of the skills that apply to their new task.

headline.main: Mother, Mentor, Baby Relief: A Navigator for the Postpartum Odyssey

docs.lead_paragraph: UNSHACKLING Oh, Brave New World . . . Call it the ultimate test of the benefits of competition. Congress finally sorted out its disagreements and passed a bill intended to promote a free-for-all among cable television and broadcasting companies, local and long-distance phone companies and who knows what from the realm of cyberspace. Each of them will be able to offer services now provided by the others. The bill's enthusiasts (only 16 members of the House and 5 senators voted against the bill) and the companies themselves say Americans will have more choices, and companies will compete through lower rates and better service. "We have broken up two of the biggest government monopolies left: local telephone service and cable TV," crowed Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, who managed the bill through the House. Consumers Union, however, predicted that cable television rates would rise, and others worried about what impact the concentration of power in the broadcasting business would have on local ownership and program content.

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1913, a fire of mysterious origin gutted Jack London's newly constructed house, which had been built to last a thousand years in this wooded hamlet north of San Francisco. Only the rock walls were left standing. Now, 83 years later, a retired engineering professor from Los Altos Hills, Calif., says he and a team of experts on fires have proved beyond doubt how the fire started, validating a theory put forward in 1980 by a London biographer.

headline.main: Discovering An Answer In the Flames

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't take my word for it, just look at the history books," Steve Forbes told the Rotary Club in Nashua this week. "Every time the tax burden is reduced, Government revenues go up, not down." That is a line Mr. Forbes delivers almost verbatim day after day, speech after speech, as he campaigns for the Republican Presidential nomination. But like many other claims he makes for his flat-tax proposal -- the issue that propelled him out of the pack and into a close race with Senator Bob Dole here in New Hampshire and in Iowa -- the proposition that past tax cuts have caused an increase in Federal revenue is difficult to document.

headline.main: A Central Fiscal Argument Advanced by Forbes Proves Hard to Confirm

docs.lead_paragraph: In a figurative sense, the crown of Miss New York never rested easily on Helen Goldsby's head, which was dizzy with the prospect of tall podiums, vast audiences, fat checks. But when she failed to trade it in for a bigger and better one -- that of Miss America, with its product endorsements and national exposure -- this lesser tiara began to feel like a dead weight on her dreams. "Becoming Miss New York was going to be the worst thing that ever happened to me," Ms. Goldsby, a 25-year-old Brooklyn resident, said recently.

headline.main: Who Rules Over a Beauty Queen?;Miss New York and Pageant Officials in a Power Struggle

docs.lead_paragraph: One outcome of this month's State Assembly race in the South Bronx seems certain: a new political dynasty will be born. One candidate, Pedro Gautier Espada, is the son of State Senator Pedro Espada Jr.; the other, Ruben Diaz Jr., is the son of the Rev. Ruben Diaz, a three-time political candidate. Indeed, politics has always been a family affair in New York City. MC MANI: New York City's most enduring political dynasty began in 1891, when Thomas J. McManus defeated an Assembly candidate fielded by the sidewalk philosopher George Washington Plunkitt on Manhattan's West Side. For most of the 140 years between the election of Fernando Wood as the first Tammany Mayor of New York and of David N. Dinkins as the last, the McMani, as Senator Daniel P. Moynihan once dubbed them, have dominated Democratic politics in Hell's Kitchen. James R. McManus, the great-nephew of Thomas J. McManus (known as "The McManus"), retired last year as a senior administrator of the city's Board of Elections but remains a Democratic district leader.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health insurance industry, which helped kill President Clinton's ambitious health care proposal in 1994, said today that it objected to a provision of a much more modest bipartisan bill to guarantee coverage for people leaving employer-sponsored health plans. Mr. Clinton endorsed the bill in his State of the Union Message last week, and it was approved unanimously in August by a Senate committee. But the bill, drafted by Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has not been called up for debate on the Senate floor, apparently because several senators have registered informal objections.

headline.main: INSURERS FIGHTING A BIPARTISAN BILL FOR HEALTH CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Signaling that inflation has been vanquished to a degree not seen since the early 1960's, the Labor Department reported today that consumer prices rose only 2.5 percent for all of 1995, the lowest rate in nearly a decade and the fifth consecutive year that inflation held to about 3 percent or less. Most economists toasted the news, saying that they expected the inflation rate to remain just as low in 1996 or to dip further. They said that this period of price stability, one of the longest since World War II, would give the Federal Reserve enough room to keep cutting interest rates, as it did on Wednesday, to spark a slowing economy.

headline.main: Prices in 1995 Up 2.5%, a 5th Subdued Year
